‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

div.head: The Olivemoor
div.p: The S.S. "Olivemoor" went into the graving dock this morning.

div.head: European Horses
div.p: Twenty Austrian horses were disembarked this morning from the S.S. "Habsburg."

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Plague regulations against arrivals from Myteline in Egyptian ports have been cancelled.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: This evening the Gemma Caimmi Italian dramatic company makes its first appearance at the Alhambra Theatre in Sardon's "Odette."

div.head: War Office.
div.p: Mohamed Said Riza has been appointed clerk to the Recruiting Department, and Yacoub Mikhail to the Financial Secretary's office.

div.head: Omdurman Station.
div.p: Work has already been commenced on the building of a shelter at the Omdurman Central Station. It is expected to be completed before the end of the present month.

div.head: A Tourist Party
div.p: A tourist party numbering twenty-four arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. "Habsburg," and left for Cairo by special train from the Custom house station.

div.head: Collapse of a House
div.p: Still another house has collapsed in Cairo, in the Targoman quarter, with fatal result. Several persons were buried under the ruins and one man when extricated was found to be dead.

div.head: Omdurman Waterworks
div.p: The contract for the tank and pipes requires for the Omdurman waterworks has been given to Messrs Orenstein and Koppel, who agree to deliver the materials required at Khartoum North before December 31.

div.head: School Inspection
div.p: Saad Pasha Zagloul, Minister of Education, has inspected the school of Khalil Aghs, and expressed his congratulations to the Direct Ali Bey Husny on the management of the school and the success gained by the pupils.

div.head: A New Egyptian Company
div.p: La Compagnie Egyptienne Houston Thomson, which has been recently formed in Belgium with a capital of five million francs, has commenced electrical operations in Egypt. The Company was floated by the Credit Franco-Egyptien.

div.head: Italian Consulates in the Sudan.
div.p: Mr. Carlo Rosetti, delegate of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who has been entrusted with the establishment of Consulates and commercial agencies in the Sudan, left Cairo yesterday for Assouan on the way to Khartoum.

div.head: Rossia Assurance Co.
div.p: The Rossia Assurance Company of St. Petersburg has entrusted the control of its Egyptian business to Mr. A. Kaden from today, the 14th inst, Mr. Th. de Kolischkine, his predecessor having been appointed by the company to a situation in Russia.

div.head: Mr. Moor and the Press
div.p: The libel actions brought by Mr. Moor, of the Ministry of Public Works, against certain local newspapers for defamatory publications in connection with the Sergani scandals, will come for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Tribumal on the 21st instant.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: The commisssion of the Egypt Railways decided at its last meeting to demand credits of L.E. 9,000 for the repairing of lines and stations in the Menoufieh province, and L.E. 10,000 for lighting purposes. The question of issuing return tickets was discussed but no decision was arrived at.

div.head: Egypt and Belgium
div.p: In the review of the report on the commercial relations between Egypt and Belgium by Mr. Charles Rueleus, which appeared in our last issue the total capital of Belgian interests here was given at four hundred thousand francs. This was an obvious misprint for four hundred million francs.

div.head: Cotton Mill Profits
div.p: In a statement issued today Mr. William Tattersall, of Manchester, says the net profit of twenty three cotton spinning companies just declared is equal to 32 per cent per annum on share capital, and 24 per cent per annum on share and loan capital combined. The total share capital of the twenty three mills is £866,234 and loans £315,180.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: A detailed account of the fifth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club, which were held on Saturday, will be found on page five. Some excellent sketches of types of manly beauty were made on this occasion by Mr. Binder, who also took some very successful photographs of the various events, and both sketches and photographs will be on view from this evening at Messrs. Reiser and Binder's in Old Bourse Street.

div.head: Cinderella in Egypt
div.p: Many of our nursery legends have an Egyptian origin, said Mr. C.J. Marshall, lecturing at the New Galley photographic exhibition last week. The story of Cinderella had its counterpart in the land of the pyramids. From time immemorial Egyptian mothers had told their children how a beautiful peasant-girl, while bathing in the Nile, was robbed of her slipper by an eagle. The slipper was taken to the King's palace, and the King- the builder of one of the great pyramids-sought for its wearer and made her his Queen.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: A LONDON SOLICITOR'S VIEW

It is satirotory to other that the recent financial embarramenta in connection with the over-speculation in Egypt-chiefly in town and suburban sites-are likely to be fraught with less serious consequences than at one time seemed probable, says the Standard". Those who have followed the matter at all closely will remember that interest has chiefly centred in the affairs of two or three wellknown names in Egyptian circles whose bille were not met at their maturity at various periods during the past few months. Many English and foreign banks were interested in the matter, and although individually the lor, had they arisen, would have been an insignificant affair, the amount collectively would have been quite snbstantial. Throughout, these banks have been seting in concert, and in their interests a solicitor, as reported by our special term of last Friday, recently went out to Egypt to consult with Accountants on the spot (also acting on behalf of the same interests, the object being to determine whe ther it was advisable to conclude arrangements whereby the payment of the bills in question could be prolonged for a given period. This gentleman has now returned, and his report, which was presented to meeting of bankers to-day, is understood to be satisfactory, both as regards the position of the individual firms in question and general financial conditions in Egypt at the present time. It would be pre mature to assume that some loses may not yet have to be faced in connection with the difficulties of the two important firms whose affairs have engaged especial attention but there is now every reason for believing that such lowes will be onder mother than over the estimates formed some few weeks ago, while the prospects of forther embarraments of any serious nature arising out of recent develop ments in Egypt seem to be steadily diminishing

div.head: Gold Importa
div.p: Gold import to the amount of £700,000 are due at Alexandria from London on Mon day next of this amount £300,000 are for the National Bank of Egypt. This bank is to re ceive a similarm in the following week and the total imports in that werk will probably amount to £700,000

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS ADMINISTRATION
THE COURT OF ENQUIRY
div.p: Dixson Bey and Ahmed Bey Kamel, Inspector of the Finance Ministry, are still actively engaged in the enquiry as to the mal practices prevalent in the Ports and Lights Administration. Much fresh evidence of an important character has lately heen die covered

Ahmed Bey Kamel has been temporarily selected to fill the place of Secretary General to the Administration, in the place of Socrates Spiro Bey, who is charged with the commission of a number of irregularities in his official posi tion and whore trial will begin on the 12th inst.

div.head:
FAMINE IN TURKEY.
INEFFECTIVE MEASURES
div.p: The situation in the provincer is alarming, The pinch of famine is already being felt in many places. The Government measures to encourage the import of wheat has had little effect (Renter)

Some time ago a Turkish Commission was appointed to inquire into the best means for putting an end to the distress due to exces Rive prices charged for bread, which presten en hardly upon the poorer classes of the popnlation throughout the Empire. As a result of the inquiry the Commission recommend that in order to cope with the difficulty it is essential that for the time being the export of wheat be prohibitel, and further, that the import duty on combe suspended, which recommendations have received the action of the Sultan. It is the oklory, that is to be heard in Turkey every year, and particularly in Constantinople. For some time past the out of living has been steadily rising per ticularly is regards fuel and bread Then, ton, the harvest prospects have falsified all hoper, so that unless steps are taken to deal with the scarcity, famine seems inevitable. But the situation and the cause of all the trouble may be summed up in a certain inci dent which lately took place at the town of Er room, towards the Persian frontier. A few weeks ago two merchants, who were sus pected of cornering wheat, were attacked and killed by an infuriated mob. This is the whole CARE Regards Tarkish distress today. Certain high officials put their heads together, and by the assistance of the middleman, set to work to exploit the consumer. It is so all over Turkey: soch economie manipulations are in themselves a trade which any official, who in Mufficiently intelligent, may practise to his full bent We expend vast amount of sympathy on the Christian subjects of the Sultan, but their lot is not one bit more haril than that of the Turkish pensant. But, when the offerer i not a Christian it does not matter.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN POLITOS
CLIQUES AND DIVISIONS
THE NATIONALIST CHEFS
div.p: The prophets who braved the public derision by foretelling the formation of political parties in Egypt at no distant date have the laugh on their side. Last spring we were informed that for all practical parposes only one party exist ed in the country-to wit the party which own Mustapha Pasha Kamel as its chief und de mands the instant withdrawal of the occupying nation' horse and foot, bag and baggage threatening it with the severe displeasure of the Egyptian people should its statesman refuse to recognise the necessity of instantly falling in with the demands formulated in and out of season by the illustrious Kamel. Today wel are confronted with quite a host of parties. Wel have the party which supports the Govern ment, the 'Liberals of Mohamed Bey Wahid, the supporters of "Al Moayad and Al Minbar, "|| the People's party and the section that has remained true to the Nationalist Pigean of the Sharia ed Dawaween. No more curious transformation could have been anticipated by the best informed student of Egyptian affairs, and we are still in the dark as to the hot importance of some of the parties which we have mentioned. Any one who questions the average intelligent Egyptian will hear the most diverse estimates of the strength of the groups or sections to which we have referred, and of the intelleet and capacity of their leaders, and we therefore give the following summaries of their opinions given by three well informed and highly intelligent young men odnoted and enlightened, whom we recently questioned on this very interesting subject :

A declared roundly that Mohamed Bey Wahid represented nobody but a group of young men of fashion who had conceived the idea that their personal interests would be threatened by a triumph of Nationalism. Of Hafiz Effendi Awad le bad little to my wave that he regarded the editor of "Al Minbar" as a mere aspirant to notoriety, the tool of Bheikh Ali Yousef, whose jealousy of the success of Mustapha Pasha Kamel bad never been concaled Sheikh Ali be held to be a political trimmer, destitute of fixed principles, & pliant but clever opponent whose motto was "reculer pour mieux suter," il contrast to Mustapha Praha who had always waged an open cam paign against the Opc spation and whose generosity, eloquence, and nergy had done wonders of late to stimulate ationalist feeling. The "Party of the People' by waved away. Conserv ative old gentlemen aspirant to political glory for whom no pla e could be found in the ranks of the elect, a host of those cautious persons whon every cr sis finds enthroned on fences, such was ita con position

B took a different was regards the snpporters of "Al Minber" and "Al Monynd." They had not formed a party, but their ideas and ideals had ondergone i decided change since they made the discovery that Nationalism Wax regarded by Karjel Pasha, whose vanity had always overborne both his prudence and his savoir faire, & monopoly to be run by himself and his faithful acolytes and that his own violence and that of his henchmen and gladiators was calculated to involve in a com mon ruin both his own projects and those of wiser men

Hafiz Awad could not speak a word in Eng land without drawing upon his band the thunders of the sole repository of patriotie virtue and Sheikh Ali Youssef had been heely attacked by the soidisant apostle of progress and liberty on the occasion of his marriage with the well born and accomplished danghter of Sheikh Sudat. He would have been more than human had be borne these insults lightly, and being a man who held strong views as to the danger of the "bag and baggage policy" advocated with threats by Mustapha Pasba, he had protested in his own name and that of his many supporters, among whom the majority if not all of the new "Party of the People" wonld ultimately be reckoned against the rashness of leader, who had no doubt done good work in his day but was too apt to imagine that the appearance of his name in the "Temps" the "Figaro" or the Times," whether the hero of the Egyptian Nationalist struggle or as the villain of a patriotic melodrama, was in itself proof of greatness

while positive that Wahid Bey's follow ing was extremely small and doubtful and whether that gentleman had not over emphasised the necessity for Fgyptians to be grateful to the occupation, averred that he had awakened the more intelligent members of the publie to the necessity of checking the ardour of Mustapha Kamel Pasha ere he drove the nationalist chariot into political quickrands and here it would assuredly be engulfed. With his poliey of revolutionary reaction he had no sympathy nor though be praised the talenta did he repose much con fidence in the leadership of Sheikh Aly Yous sef Hafiz Effendi Awad had undoubtedly certain gifts but he was unlikely to carry weight with more than a small section of the population and, though better acquainted than Mustapha Pasha Kamel with the English char acter -- an important consideration this for nationalist leader, lacked his prestige and eloquence. The "People's Party" representeil the common sense of vast number of Egyp tians who mw that nothing was to be gained by threats and bluster, but that moob, perhaps oventual independence or self-rule might be won by the avoidance of the policy of irritating the occupants and by the adoption of X constructive programe of reform. This was the party which was destined to survive; No tonalism had come to stay, but with every year the Oooupants would recognise that the

Egyptian people bad not been fairly represented in the past and that save in the name there was littleconnection between the Custini of irresponsible demagogues and the progressive and liberal policy of men who bads stake in country,
Our readers can chose the version of oorrent events that plenses them best.

div.head: SLAVERY IN DARFUR
div.p: "The Sudan Times" learns from one who is fairly well acquainted with the affairs of Darfor that the slave trade is still practised in that country. He says that there are regular slave-markets where slaves are exhibited for sale, just as it used to be in the past. The pilgrims who go to the Hedjaz Kenerally take along with them a number of male and female slaves on the pretext that they are body servants. On the retom of these pilgrims from Mecca, very few of their slaves return with them. They claim that they had been carried off by disease or had preferred to live for the rest of their lives in the neigh bourhood of the holy places. It is alleged, however, that they are sold in Arabia. We cannot vouch for the accuracy of these state ments, continues our contemporary, but the matter certainly deserves attention. The odions slave trade which has already been success folly stamped out from all other parts of the Sudan shonld not be tolerated in Darfur

div.head: TRE PORTS AND LIGHTS ADMINISTRATION
div.p: To The Borror Or Ter BGYPTIAN GAZETTE | Sir.- notice that a recent contribution of mine to your columns biss ovoked some eri ticism in the Cairo Nationalist Press. I to marked, in reference to the present political situation in Egypt, that there is always a very striking example before the public wye of an administration runon potely Reyptian me thods without any interference from Europeans, for the manner in which the Wakfs Administration is managed affords an object lesson.
Your Nationalist contemporary makes the following rejoinder :

"We should like to ask the Oniro Corres pondent of the Rgyptian Gazette" if to his knowledge any Parts and Lighthouses scandals have taken place in the Wakho Administration No ! Thon with what right, or sopported by what Argaments can be spent against this administration

"Give the Egyptians a fair triand Britishen will see that they are by moments inferior to Butopeans or Americans. What is more, dals like the recent one in the Ports and Lighthouse Administration (superintended by Englishment !) will not be more frequent than they are to-day, nor perpetrated on snob - wholesale scale as in some Huropean con tries

Now to adduce the unfortunate scandal, which have recently been brought to light in the Ports and Lights Administration whexample of English mismanagement of Reyptian sihin is quite beside the point. The terrible state of affnin prevailing in that Administration has been made public because it is unler English control and hause the English Adriers of the Bgyptian Government are determined, far as posible, to stand out the bridens taint of corruption in the various Government departments. Your Nationalist contothporary appears to think that becadise bnch malpro tices bare not been brought to light in regard to the management of the Wakt Administration that it is credit to a purely Egyptian-run depertinent are many friends among the batives and if they say is true about the Wakfs Administration for that that department is in quite as parlous a state as the unfortunate Ports and bighie Administration. But in the one on the red state of things has not been made publiebe Ause it is nonaged as a purely native sondern while in the latter case the light of day has been let in on a festering mass of corruption thanks to the energy of its English administrators.

div.head:
THE ENGLISHMAN SWINDLED.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE BOYPTIAN GAZETA.
div.p: Dear Sir.- The following extracts from the price list of the café in the Esbekieh Gardens afford an excellent example of the degree to which efforts are made to "rush" the uninitinted Briglishmen. The price list is printed on one side in French and on the other in English, as follows:
P.14 PRICE LA Glescher P T S Appollinare Klach Kun Ath. 3 TARI CONCOVATIONS Che Appollini Sire de ren tre Kummel

The Boglishman naturally tuma his attention to the English-printed side of the price list and for doing so has the privilege of paying an advanced rate of from 20 to 38 %. Consider ing that on the two evenings on which our military hands play in the Gardens, the atten dance of Englishmen numbers some hundreds the café sbould make a considerable profit by this somewhat questionable method of catering
Yours faithfully
ONCE A VIOTTM.
Caim, October 2.

div.head:
ST. FRANCIS SCHOOL
PRIZE DISTRIBUTION.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the annual distribution of prizes to the pupils of the Saint Francis Sehool, Al Manayer, Alexandria, was held under the presidence of H.B. Mgr. Aurelio Briante. The pupils with their parents and friends assembled in full numbers in the school ground, which had been lavishly decorated for the occasion. The day was also the feast day of the Saint in whose name the school is conse crated. During the afternoon an excellent programme, which was opened with a hearty rendering of the Khedivial anthem, was performed, and every item was warmly Ypplauded. The entertainment inoluded drums comedy, and song and in each of these the pupils showed themselves thoroughly profi cient. The prizes were distributed by the Very Rev. Father Guardian, Assisted the Rev. Pather Anmtasins, the principal prise being awarded to the head-boy, Theodore Aborous Prines of honor were also awarded to Prancis Tarascio and Louis Fontane, and the prizes for English, French, and Arabie want to peet ively to Artha Messina, Theodore Abouton and Alfred Magre. The school will open for the ordinary classes et Monday

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui el midi)

Le marche, favorablement influence par le Stock Exchange, a fait preuve de soutien; plusieurs valeurs ont meme beneficie d'une nouvelle avance, qui a ete pour quelqies unes fort appreciable. Dans l'empomble, pourtant, on s'a ttendait a mieax et la vlotute, un pea plus faible que le debut, a ete une desillusion pour un certain nombre. Inutile d'ajouter que les transactions sout reateas clarsombeset limited en comme importance a quatre ou cinq valeurs. Malgre le flechissement de la fin, la tendunce demeure plutot ferme.

Parmi les titres en faveur qui ont ete l'objct de la plupart des echanges il faut eiter l'Agricole, le Comptoir, la Cassa di Sconto et l'Union Foneiere. En Behera il s'est produit une demande tres active qui n'a quere eu d'autre resultat que de faire monter le cours de 22 1/4 23 1/2 faute de vendears. Il a'agirait d'aeheteurs serieux. L'Agricole, favoriese d'achats de la part d'arbitragiates pour compte de Londres, a progrease de ce chef de 8 5/16 a 8 7/16, prix anquel elle a cleture acheteurs. La Cassa, qui continue a ecouler parpetits paquets son enorme portefeuille titres, a gagne 50 centimes a 54 1/2. De jour en jour plus demandree, l'Union Fenciere s'est avancee de 4 15/16 a acheteurs. Quant an Comptoir, apres avoir ouvert en pleine effervescence a 3 3/8 avec affaires relativement nombreuses, il a fini plus faible a 3 3/16 l'ancienne action et 3 1/4 la nouvelle, soit au meme niveau que vendiedi dernier; la fondateur a meme perdu 1/4 a 2 1/4.

D'abord recherchee avec quelques rres transactions, la National Bank a termine efforte a 22 1/16, a cause d'ordres de vente provenant du Cairo. Ce prix n'en constitute pas moins une plus value de 1/8.
Il y a eu egalement quelques afrarres en Lunghis et Levant, tandis que l'United a ete totalement negligue a 9/32 vendeurs l'action et 1 7/16 la fondateur, contre 9/32 achaeur et 1 1/2 [NON-LEGIBLE].

La Delta Light a flechi de 10 5/16 a 10 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Cairo de 135 a 194 et les Nungovieh Hotels de 18 3/4 a 17 1/2. D'astre part, l'Obligation Credit Fongier ancienne emission a progresse de 303 a 304, tandis que la nouvelle a retrograde de 257 a 256 1/12 vendeurs. L'Urbaine a hausse de 3 13/16 a 3 7/8.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, la Delta Land arecule de 1 23/32 a 1 21/32 et la Building Lands de 2 5/16 a 2 1/4, tandis que l"ordinary Khedivial Mail a avamou de 21/- a 21/3 et la Levant de 9/16 a 19/32.
Il a ete vendu es matin aux enecheres publiques 100 actions anciennes Upper Egypt Hotels a 2 7/8 et 40 nouvelles a 2 1/2, 200

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTRE ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Jondi 8 Octobre Le taux de l'escompte libre Londres est renseigne en hausse de 1/8 24 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais avancé hier de 1/8 à 82 1/2.L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102. la National Bank a gagné 1/4 à 22 1/2. L'Agricole a été ferme à 8 1/2 et la Dairs à 14. La Delta Light s'est inscrite a 10 1/2 en hausse de 1/4.
A Paris: le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a été soutenu à 702. La Banque d'Athènes a perda 1 frane à 112. Les Lots Turos se sont raffermis à 171.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Notional Bank avance à 22 5/16. L'Agricole se tanne à 8 S.S. La Banque d'Orient est demandée 120 121. Le Comptoir Financier recule à 2 7/8 et sa partà Les fondateurs Société Générale housent à 48-44. La fondateur f. de Vries and Boutigny Limited s'est inscrite en nouvelle arahoe & 7 3/8

La Delta Lightest ferme à 101/4. Les Jouis nees Eaux du Caire ont un bon courant d'affaires à 195-196. La Dairs Sanieh monte à 18 7/8. LA Bébés se relève 20 1/4. L'action Allotment est recherchée à 2 8/8-7/16 et les tondateurs rétrogradent PT. 64. La Société des Entreprises Immobilières et Travailx très en faveur atteint 2 3/16 tandis que les parts de foudateur sont l'objet d'un fort mouvement en clôture qui les porte P.T. 19. les fondateurs Heliopolis sont en forte tendance à 11 7/8-12 L'Union Poncière accentue sa reprise à 484 Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nongovich réactionnent 15 5/8 contre 16 hier. Les Baebler ne réveillent . 61/8. Les National Hotels se consolident à 2 1/2 et leur part mollit a P.T.30. Parmi les petites valeurs, la New Egyptian est plus faible 13/9-14. L'Aboukir est en meilleure disposition à 29/ La Salt and Soda retombe à 18/-18/. Les Ciments gagnent 1 franc à 37, alors que la part fléchit á 9. les Abdy progressent légèrement à 012-9/16
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres les passages suivants :

"Notre marché a passé par l'asser fortes angoisses au cours de la semaine en revne, angoisses causées par la chute du cuivre, et les marvaines nouvelles d'Amérique on le prési dent Roosevelt affirme de plus fort son intention de continuer sa campagne contre les trusts
"Comme affaires, le Stock Exchange est calme, mais on prévoit sous peu une reprise que la situation monétaire favorable rend this probable.

"Vos valeurs égyptiennes trouvent des acheteurs convaincus, surtout la National Bank, Agricultural Bank et Daima Sanieh. Les der nières nouvelles de la récolte du enton et l'assurance que l'Egypte trouvera l'aide financière qui lui est nécessaire chaque automne, ont pro voqué une nouvelle demande sur les valeurs égyptiennes garanties, qui ont haussé d'autant. Il est probable que les cours se relèveront encore davantage étant donné que c'est le portefeuille qui achète et non les professionnels. "Le dernier bilan de la Banque d'Angleterre montre l'aisance avec laquelle elle a pu faire face aux tirages contre sa caisse. On s'attend cependant une légère tension du taux de l'escompte, vu les demandes d'argent qui affluent à Lombard Street."

"Le dernier bilan de la Banque d'Angleterre montre l'aisance avec laquelle elle a pu faire face aux tirages contre sa caisse. On s'attend cependant une légère tension du taux de l'es compte, vu les demandes d'argent qui affluent la Lombard Street."

On annonce que le 27 Septembre dernier, un certain nombre d'actionnaires égyptiens et européens de la "Walker and Maimarachi Ltd." ont déposé au siège social de la Compagnie, une demande de convocation pour une assem blée générale extraordinaire dans le but de transférer au Caire le contrôle des affaires de la Société, actuellement à Londres.
Pour la semaine au 28 Septembre, les recettes des "Tramways d'Alexandrie" ne sont élevées à LE 1,987 contre LB 1,775 pour la semaine correspondante en 1906 soit un excédent de LE. 162.
Depuis le début de l'année, eller acousent une plus value de LB. 11.669. Pour la semaine su 28 Septembre tooulé, les recettes de l' "Alexandria And Rainle Rail ways sont élevées LE 1,969 coutre LE
99 pendant la période correspondantom 1906, soit une plus-value de LR 876. Depuis le der Octobre 1906 les recettes totales sont en augmentation de LE 9,802.

Camet de l'actionnaire MM. les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Invest ment and Ageney It" sont informes que par décision du Conseil d'Administration, le troisieme et dernier versement de 5 shellings par nction est appelé à partir de 17 Décembre 1907.
Les versements doivent etre effectada aux guichets de l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. à Londres ou à Alexandrie.

div.head:
THE AMERICAN NAVY.
ROOSEVELT ADVOCATES INCREASE

div.p: President Roosevelt, speaking at Cairo (Illinois), advocating the increase of the navy declared that the polioy of peace with insult was as bad for a nation as for an individual. He hoped bereafter that the policy of keeping the battleship fleet alternately in the Pacific and Atlantic would be steadily followed (Renster)
The "New York Herald" announces the engagement of Miss Gladys Vanderbilt, daughter of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt, to the Hungarian Count Laszlo Scerchenyi. (Reuter)
Newspapers of all shades condemn the weakness of Russia in Macedonia and declare that the Slavs are being humiliated to benefit Greece (Renter)

Speaking at Villeneuve-sur-Lot M. Pallières said that he was convinced that the new gene rations, instructed by the past, would complish all the duties of man and citizen and would place above everything love of the country and the flag
(Hanas)
M. Pallières has returned here. (Reuter)
The employer of the milways have adopter passive resistance and the train service is suffering greatly
. 100 of Muley Hafid's horsemen entered Mazagan by # use and arrested the Governor, whom they sent to Marrakesh, and installed a new Governor. (Reuter)
. Mouley Hafid has arrested the Governor of the town, who has been brought to Marakesh in chains (Hans)

2,000 girl strikers from Clarks Thread Mills at Paisley attacked and severely ill-treated the girls working at Coats Mill at Perguslie. The fire bose failed to disperse them and the con tabulary was requisitioned. The strikers then peted the men. Messrs. Conts have locked out their hands at Ferguslie, giving them full pay until they are secured against intimidation. 12,000 workers are idle. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KRARLAY AND CUNNINGHAM' WERKLY REPORT

LIVERPOOL, September 26, The demand for Egyptian Cotton still draga, and only a small hand to mouth business is done. The quotation of Polly Good Fair Brown is unchanged; all other qualities are 1/16 plb. lower, and Uppers are reduced 3/16 plb. for the week.
Egyptian Futures have been fairly active, and the following are the latest quotations :Sep. 9.58 Dec. 9.46 Mar. 9.43 Oct. 9.54 Jan. 9.48 Apr. 9.42 Nov. 9.54 Feb. 9.43 May 9.42

American Futures. The market this week has been more active, and prices have ex perienced sharp fluctuations. At one time the decline amounted to 204 @ 21 points, of which subsequently 14 points, were recovered, to-day's closing values being 9 @ 10 points below those of last Thursday

Continued beavy liquidatiou, considerable "Bear" selling, and the reversing of straddles upon Liverpool, besides the 'bedge" selling against purchases of actual Cotton, completely broke the Market. Since Tuesday, however, there has been less pressure to sell, Southern holders are firmer with actual Cotton and there has been some covering by the "Bears."

The accounts of the Crop are at present quite favorable, but we are approaching the October Bureau report, also the period of the equinoxes and lower temperatures, and there is likely to be more sensitiveness and less aggressive action by the bear section of the various markets.
The latest values are delivery September. 6.28 Deo/Jan. 6.021 April/May 6.041 Bept./Oct. 6.13 Jan/Feb. 6.02 May/June 6.05 Oct./Nov. 6.004 Feb/Mar. 6.03 Nov./Der 6,04 Mar Apl. 6.04

div.head: SHORTAGE OF OFFICERS IN INDIA
div.p: There is a considerable shortage of British officers for the Indian army, and it is stated that Lord Kitchener bas recently appealed to the home authorities to spare him as many officers as they possibly can to bring up several native regiments to their proper strength. For some reason or another service in the Indian army is not nearly so popular as it ased to be, and there has been some talk the "Manchester Guardian" stater, of the establishment of a small committee by the Indian Government to consider how far it might be possible to revise the present conditions of service, pay, &, in order to make the nativearmy more attractive to young officers. At present, through the abolition of several infantry battalions at home, there is a supply of officers on full pay doing no work, and it is hoped that many of these may be induced to volunteer for service with the Indian native anny

div.head: FATHER AND DAGHTER'S LOCKS
div.p: Signor Viteli, of Capri, is being sued by his two daughters in singular circumstances. The young ladies, who are respectively 20 and 17 years of age, until Intely attracted around themselves a crowd of admirers by reason of their beauty, fret which aroused their father's anger

The latter hit opon a novel plan to rid his daughters of their followers. He summoned a barber and compelled him to save the beads of both girls, who had previously pasensed the most beautiful hair, much fairer than that of the majority of Italian women. Th resultant action for damages will show wbether the unsentimental father was within his rights.

div.head: THE EGYPTIANS OF TO-DAY.
div.p: The receitly published work of the late Haji A. Browne "Bonaparte in Egypt and the Egyptians Today," is the subject of a long and appre iative review in the "Athenaeum," from which we extract the following

That the Egyptians are the mildest the most docile and perhaps the politest of all Fastern per ples we agree with the author. That they are also the least warlike may be confidently asset ted. Notwithstanding they can be turbulent upon occasions, especially when they foney they wave nothing to fear, which seems to us cowardly, Occasion, opportunity, is every thing with them and what seems to be in demand at the moment they are ever ready and eager to sipply. There was a clear demand in Barope for Egyptian "Nationalism and the journalists of Cairo and others produced the thing at once, full grown. On this point Haji Abdallah had no illusions. We are toll here plainly that the Egyptians do not desire representative government. That any one should have imagined that they could As a race desire a boon so shotmot, shows the depth of Enlish ignorance of Eastern thought, and the crying need of such a book as this. The ides o labour for nowage, for the common well, is absurd and repugnant to all their notion. They have a proverb to the following efl xet :

We ohserve throughout the book a certain tendency in the author to simplify his hypotheses by the mission of some potent factor. The faults o the Egyptian, where todohed upon, are 80 treated us to seem like vir thes; and thus the whole ongs of the recent strained relations between the two races is thrown upon the English, for whom, with the important exception of Lord Cromer, he has fow good words. That a large proportion of our fellow-countrymen deserve to be classified as "oads," when judged by an Oriental stan dard of good breeding, iswe fear true. But it is not fair to judge them solely by that stan dard, and we have noticed in Egypt, among the rising generation, an inclination to view their mien and bearing in a humorous light, which should tend to smooth matters, since the Egyptian is wont to tolerate what makes him laugh. In this connection we must hazard a doubt whether a wish to procure only publie school and university men for posts in Egypt is altogether in accord with wisdom. The youth fresh from those excellent institutions is apt to west, as his natural skin, a look and a man ner, which-though it is not unlikely be may never discover the fact-are not beloved in Egypt. It is commonly the unofficial Englishman who makes himself offensive to the natives, point that is not bere brought out with sufficient cleaness; and if even the most polite and sympathetic of the English residenta do not fraternize with the Egyptians, it is owing, not to racial pride, but to the different views of the two nations m to the statuts of woman, a point which the Haji has not even mentioned. This last is bar to social intimacy, more effectual than the difference of religion.

The average Egyptian sees but one thing at a time, and but one aspect of the thing-often only some minor detail. He seems incapable of & general view. This is well stated in the opening pages; but we doubt whether the statement would have any meaning for a reader unacquainted with the folk in question. Take their songs, for instance. The Arabic singer throws out phrase, a note or two, then pauses for applause. The individual notes, the details, are more important than the tone, the whole. And any one stating a problem or a riddle to uneducated Egyptians will be astonished by their evident preoccupation with the mere words. Withal, possessing sense of fictional truth, of the point and teaching of a story, which might be envied by many a European, they take no pleasure in frets. This (the Haji has not mentioned) is a main cause of their failure to comprehend the Englishman, whose sense of fictional truth is often of the dallest. A people dwelling in imagination, short-sighted in its vision of the actual, confronted with the most matter of-fact of human races, clear sighted only for material things: no wonder there are calls for an interpreter

| The author's plen for the serious considera tion of Pan-Islamism has the warm sympathy of the present reviewer. It is a great cause, and its merits are here clearly set forth for the enlightenment of a publio which has probably heard it referred to vaguely as some kind of peril.

div.head: GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S CENTENARY.
div.p: The centenary celebration of the Geological Society of London were opened at the Instite tion of Civil Engineen, Westminster, last Thursday and were attended by delegates from all parts of the world. An interesting feature of the proceedings was the reception held by the President, Sir Archibald Geikio, at which addresses of congratulation were pre sented by the foreign and colonial delegates Bight addresses were received from German Universities and societies, and delegates from the Universities and learned societies of Great Britain also acknowledged the debt which science owed to the Geological Society. An address from the Government o Egypt was presented by Captain H. G. Lyons (Director of the Geological Survey of Egypt), who wid that the society had always been in the forefront of advance in knowledge,

During the reception Mr. C. J. Alford (of the Egyptian Mines Explortion Co.) on behalf of the Institution of Mining and Metallurgy. presented the gold medal of that society to Sir Archibald Geikie, in recognition of the services rendered by Geology to the mining industry

THE PRESIDENTIAL ADI RESS. The principal event of the aftertoon session was the delivery of the presidental address by Sir Archibald Geikie. The subject of the ad. dress was "The State of Geology at the Time of the Pormation of the Society." At the outset he said that no more signal proof of the real brotherhood of science could be afforded than by the present assembly of delegates from all parts of the world. Plunging into his historical retrospect, the president traced the progress of knowledge as to the structure and surface of the eatth from the wild, speculations of other days to the mediaeval period in which soclesiastical dogma resisted the progress of inquiry. During the Middle Agen heresy was unpopular as well w dan gerous, but by the end of the eighteenth cen tary the hand of the Church had relaxed its bold.

| It had been said that the geologist ought never to forget that the mineralogist was his father. But, if the geologist was to own the mineralogistas his father, he must surely acknow ledge the miner to be his grandfather. For many centuries most of the current knowledge of the rooks and minerals of the earth's crust was gained by those who worked in mines, and when miners established mining schools for the practical training of those who were to follow their craft, they took an important step forward in paving the way for the creation of a sound geology

Closing with a eulogy of the society's work, Sir Archibald said that its fellow and foreign members comprised most of the illustrious geologists of the time. To the influence of a few of its lenders was to great extent due the establishment of the Geological Survey in Great Britain na national institution. A century so full of progress alike in the theoretical develop ment and the practical application of geology gave the best augury of advancement in the centary
At night the official dinner was held at the Whitehall Rooms On Friday the delegates visited the London in soms and were entertained to dinner by the Geological Society Club.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de 200 regards de visite en fonte et 400 grilles de puinards conformément aux dessins et spécifications du cahier des charges
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE : 78.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an bureau Technique où il pent etre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 22 Octobre 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en sance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en ontre la mention: Soumission pour fourniture de regards de visite en fonte et grilles. .

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions de cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au service de la Comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 19 Octobre & midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera foarte Alexandrie le 2/10/01

div.p: The recent sinual report of the Commie sioners of Inland Revenue characterises as remarkable" the increase from £66,000,000 to nearly £74,000,000 in the ed amount of the income from foreign investments for 1905-6 m compared with that for the previous year, whereas the previous mate of increase for some years bad not much exceeded one million pounds a year.
